author: HCAndersen
text: IN the midst of a garden grew a rose-tree, in full blossom, and in the prettiest of all the roses lived an elf.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was such a little wee thing, that no human eye could see him.

author: HCAndersen
text: Behind each leaf of the rose he had a sleeping chamber.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was as well formed and as beautiful as a little child could be, and had wings that reached from his shoulders to his feet.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, what sweet fragrance there was in his chambers! and how clean and beautiful were the walls! for they were the blushing leaves of the rose.

author: HCAndersen
text: During the whole day he enjoyed himself in the warm sunshine, flew from flower to flower, and danced on the wings of the flying butterflies.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he took it into his head to measure how many steps he would have to go through the roads and cross-roads that are on the leaf of a linden-tree.

author: HCAndersen
text: What we call the veins on a leaf, he took for roads; ay, and very long roads they were for him; for before he had half finished his task, the sun went down: he had commenced his work too late.

author: HCAndersen
text: It became very cold, the dew fell, and the wind blew; so he thought the best thing he could do would be to return home.

author: HCAndersen
text: He hurried himself as much as he could; but he found the roses all closed up, and he could not get in; not a single rose stood open.

author: HCAndersen
text: The poor little elf was very much frightened.

author: HCAndersen
text: He had never before been out at night, but had always slumbered secretly behind the warm rose-leaves.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, this would certainly be his death.

author: HCAndersen
text: At the other end of the garden, he knew there was an arbor, overgrown with beautiful honey-suckles.

author: HCAndersen
text: The blossoms looked like large painted horns; and he thought to himself, he would go and sleep in one of these till the morning.

author: HCAndersen
text: He flew thither; but "hush!" two people were in the arbor,- a handsome young man and a beautiful lady.

author: HCAndersen
text: They sat side by side, and wished that they might never be obliged to part.

author: HCAndersen
text: They loved each other much more than the best child can love its father and mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But we must part," said the young man; "your brother does not like our engagement, and therefore he sends me so far away on business, over mountains and seas.

author: HCAndersen
text: Farewell, my sweet bride; for so you are to me."

author: HCAndersen
text: And then they kissed each other, and the girl wept, and gave him a rose; but before she did so, she pressed a kiss upon it so fervently that the flower opened.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the little elf flew in, and leaned his head on the delicate, fragrant walls.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here he could plainly hear them say, "Farewell, farewell;" and he felt that the rose had been placed on the young man's breast.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, how his heart did beat!

author: HCAndersen
text: The little elf could not go to sleep, it thumped so loudly.

author: HCAndersen
text: The young man took it out as he walked through the dark wood alone, and kissed the flower so often and so violently, that the little elf was almost crushed.

author: HCAndersen
text: He could feel through the leaf how hot the lips of the young man were, and the rose had opened, as if from the heat of the noonday sun.

author: HCAndersen
text: There came another man, who looked gloomy and wicked.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was the wicked brother of the beautiful maiden.

author: HCAndersen
text: He drew out a sharp knife, and while the other was kissing the rose, the wicked man stabbed him to death; then he cut off his head, and buried it with the body in the soft earth under the linden-tree.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now he is gone, and will soon be forgotten," thought the wicked brother; "he will never come back again.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was going on a long journey over mountains and seas; it is easy for a man to lose his life in such a journey.

author: HCAndersen
text: My sister will suppose he is dead; for he cannot come back, and she will not dare to question me about him."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he scattered the dry leaves over the light earth with his foot, and went home through the darkness; but he went not alone, as he thought,- the little elf accompanied him.

author: HCAndersen
text: He sat in a dry rolled-up linden-leaf, which had fallen from the tree on to the wicked man's head, as he was digging the grave.

author: HCAndersen
text: The hat was on the head now, which made it very dark, and the little elf shuddered with fright and indignation at the wicked deed.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was the dawn of morning before the wicked man reached home; he took off his hat, and went into his sister's room.

author: HCAndersen
text: There lay the beautiful, blooming girl, dreaming of him whom she loved so, and who was now, she supposed, travelling far away over mountain and sea.

author: HCAndersen
text: Her wicked brother stopped over her, and laughed hideously, as fiends only can laugh.

author: HCAndersen
text: The dry leaf fell out of his hair upon the counterpane; but he did not notice it, and went to get a little sleep during the early morning hours.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the elf slipped out of the withered leaf, placed himself by the ear of the sleeping girl, and told her, as in a dream, of the horrid murder; described the place where her brother had slain her lover, and buried his body; and told her of the linden-tree, in full blossom, that stood close by.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That you may not think this is only a dream that I have told you," he said, "you will find on your bed a withered leaf."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she awoke, and found it there.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, what bitter tears she shed! and she could not open her heart to any one for relief.

author: HCAndersen
text: The window stood open the whole day, and the little elf could easily have reached the roses, or any of the flowers; but he could not find it in his heart to leave one so afflicted.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the window stood a bush bearing monthly roses.

author: HCAndersen
text: He seated himself in one of the flowers, and gazed on the poor girl.

author: HCAndersen
text: Her brother often came into the room, and would be quite cheerful, in spite of his base conduct; so she dare not say a word to him of her heart's grief.

author: HCAndersen
text: As soon as night came on, she slipped out of the house, and went into the wood, to the spot where the linden-tree stood; and after removing the leaves from the earth, she turned it up, and there found him who had been murdered.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, how she wept and prayed that she also might die!

author: HCAndersen
text: Gladly would she have taken the body home with her; but that was impossible; so she took up the poor head with the closed eyes, kissed the cold lips, and shook the mould out of the beautiful hair.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I will keep this," said she; and as soon as she had covered the body again with the earth and leaves, she took the head and a little sprig of jasmine that bloomed in the wood, near the spot where he was buried, and carried them home with her.

author: HCAndersen
text: As soon as she was in her room, she took the largest flower-pot she could find, and in this she placed the head of the dead man, covered it up with earth, and planted the twig of jasmine in it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Farewell, farewell," whispered the little elf.

author: HCAndersen
text: He could not any longer endure to witness all this agony of grief, he therefore flew away to his own rose in the garden.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the rose was faded; only a few dry leaves still clung to the green hedge behind it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Alas! how soon all that is good and beautiful passes away," sighed the elf.

author: HCAndersen
text: After a while he found another rose, which became his home, for among its delicate fragrant leaves he could dwell in safety.

author: HCAndersen
text: Every morning he flew to the window of the poor girl, and always found her weeping by the flower pot.

author: HCAndersen
text: The bitter tears fell upon the jasmine twig, and each day, as she became paler and paler, the sprig appeared to grow greener and fresher.

author: HCAndersen
text: One shoot after another sprouted forth, and little white buds blossomed, which the poor girl fondly kissed.

author: HCAndersen
text: But her wicked brother scolded her, and asked her if she was going mad.

author: HCAndersen
text: He could not imagine why she was weeping over that flower-pot, and it annoyed him.

author: HCAndersen
text: He did not know whose closed eyes were there, nor what red lips were fading beneath the earth.

author: HCAndersen
text: And one day she sat and leaned her head against the flower-pot, and the little elf of the rose found her asleep.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he seated himself by her ear, talked to her of that evening in the arbor, of the sweet perfume of the rose, and the loves of the elves.

author: HCAndersen
text: Sweetly she dreamed, and while she dreamt, her life passed away calmly and gently, and her spirit was with him whom she loved, in heaven.

author: HCAndersen
text: And the jasmine opened its large white bells, and spread forth its sweet fragrance; it had no other way of showing its grief for the dead.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the wicked brother considered the beautiful blooming plant as his own property, left to him by his sister, and he placed it in his sleeping room, close by his bed, for it was very lovely in appearance, and the fragrance sweet and delightful.

author: HCAndersen
text: The little elf of the rose followed it, and flew from flower to flower, telling each little spirit that dwelt in them the story of the murdered young man, whose head now formed part of the earth beneath them, and of the wicked brother and the poor sister.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We know it," said each little spirit in the flowers, "we know it, for have we not sprung from the eyes and lips of the murdered one.

author: HCAndersen
text: We know it, we know it," and the flowers nodded with their heads in a peculiar manner.

author: HCAndersen
text: The elf of the rose could not understand how they could rest so quietly in the matter, so he flew to the bees, who were gathering honey, and told them of the wicked brother.

author: HCAndersen
text: And the bees told it to their queen, who commanded that the next morning they should go and kill the murderer.

author: HCAndersen
text: But during the night, the first after the sister's death, while the brother was sleeping in his bed, close to where he had placed the fragrant jasmine, every flower cup opened, and invisibly the little spirits stole out, armed with poisonous spears.

author: HCAndersen
text: They placed themselves by the ear of the sleeper, told him dreadful dreams and then flew across his lips, and pricked his tongue with their poisoned spears.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now have we revenged the dead," said they, and flew back into the white bells of the jasmine flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: When the morning came, and as soon as the window was opened, the rose elf, with the queen bee, and the whole swarm of bees, rushed in to kill him.

author: HCAndersen
text: But he was already dead.

author: HCAndersen
text: People were standing round the bed, and saying that the scent of the jasmine had killed him.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the elf of the rose understood the revenge of the flowers, and explained it to the queen bee, and she, with the whole swarm, buzzed about the flower-pot.

author: HCAndersen
text: The bees could not be driven away.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then a man took it up to remove it, and one of the bees stung him in the hand, so that he let the flower-pot fall, and it was broken to pieces.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then every one saw the whitened skull, and they knew the dead man in the bed was a murderer.

author: HCAndersen
text: And the queen bee hummed in the air, and sang of the revenge of the flowers, and of the elf of the rose and said that behind the smallest leaf dwells One, who can discover evil deeds, and punish them also.
